My work philosophy is creating meaningful impact by letting facts and numbers guide decisions.

title: The Ole Store Restaurant â€“ Google Reviews Analysis
text:
By Kyrylo Koltunov

My mini project examines Google reviews for one of my favorite places to dine in Northfield, MN â€” The Ole Store Restaurant. Known for its Norwegian and European cuisine, this place holds a special place in the community. With over 800 Google reviews, it offers a rich dataset for meaningful text analysis.
The goal of this project is to explore the psychology of customer feedback, understand trends in positive and negative reviews, and highlight linguistic patterns in user-generated comments.



ðŸ“Œ Insert scatterplot image here
The first scatterplot shows that the longest reviews were mostly written for 5-star ratings, while reviews with 4, 3, 2, or 1 stars tended to be shorter or even empty. Many 1-star reviews consisted of only a few words or no text at all.
Positive reviews tend to be longer because people are more inclined to describe enjoyable experiences. Negative reviewers often use minimal effortâ€”unless a situation was extremely upsetting, in which case the text becomes much longer (e.g., a 600-character 1-star outlier).




ðŸ“Œ Insert 3-word-cloud image here


Dominated by positive vocabulary such as amazing, friendly, delicious, fantastic, and excellent. The overall tone emphasizes quality, atmosphere, and hospitality.



Contain fewer adjectives and more neutral nouns. Themes mention slow service, overcooked dishes, and mixed experiences.



Focus on dissatisfaction: waitress, disappointing, cold, staff, hair, breakfast.
Words like girlfriend and left reflect emotionally charged experiences.





ðŸ“Œ Insert sentiment pie charts here
Sentiment results show:

5-star reviews: ~80% positive

3-star reviews: ~60% positive

1-star reviews: ~50% positive (surprisingly balanced)

This reveals that even negative reviewers often use polite or partially positive wording. Overall, sentiment distribution is well balanced.




ðŸ“Œ Insert positive mind map image here
The mind map highlights:

delicious food
excellent service
fresh ingredients
friendly staff
wide breakfast selection
reasonable prices
wonderful brunch

Strengths consistently revolve around quality and atmosphere.




ðŸ“Œ Insert negative mind map image here
Key negative themes include:

issues with cheese quality

disappointing dishes

rolled eggs and rice soup

table experience problems

concerns about freshness

inconsistent service

Negative feedback often centers around specific items rather than general disapproval.




The Ole Store Restaurant is widely appreciated for its fresh dishes, friendly staff, and welcoming atmosphere. Critical comments are less frequent and typically focus on specific menu items or service delays.
A key psychological insight:
Positive reviewers tend to write longer texts, while negative reviews are frequently short or emptyâ€”except when emotions run high.





Expand visualization variety for deeper insights

Investigate seasonal or monthly fluctuations in review patterns

Explore temporal sentiment trends

Attempt to extract timestamps from reviews if possible in the future

text:
ðŸ“Œ Insert scatterplot image here
The first scatterplot shows that the longest reviews were mostly written for 5-star ratings, while reviews with 4, 3, 2, or 1 stars tended to be shorter or even empty. Many 1-star reviews consisted of only a few words or no text at all.
Positive reviews tend to be longer because people are more inclined to describe enjoyable experiences. Negative reviewers often use minimal effortâ€”unless a situation was extremely upsetting, in which case the text becomes much longer (e.g., a 600-character 1-star outlier).

title: Text_Analysis
text:
IMAGE GOES HERE
The left cloud (5-star reviews) includes overwhelmingly positive vocabulary: food, amazing, friendly, delicious, fantastic, etc. It highlights excellent service, desserts, and friendly staff.
The middle cloud (3-star reviews) contains more neutral nouns and fewer adjectives. Reviewers mention issues such as slow service or overcooked dishes.
The right cloud (1-star reviews) centers on dissatisfaction: waitress, disappointing, staff, cold, hair, average breakfast. Some unique outliers like girlfriend or left indicate strong emotional responses.

title: Text_Analysis
text:
IMAGE GOES HERE
The tone analysis shows:

5-star reviews â†’ ~80% positive

3-star reviews â†’ ~60% positive

1-star reviews â†’ surprisingly ~50% positive

This suggests that even many low-star reviewers still include polite or positive language. With ~800 reviews, the sentiment distribution appears balanced and fair.
